title: Color
content:
We're all aware that the old 4 color games looked like crap, except maybe Keen 4 CGA, which was pretty damn good.

Now, the 16 color games are different; I often find myself annoyed by the limitation of color in Keen when building tiles, yet I'm also amazed at just how incredible some of Id and apogee's games turned out, all in 16 colors.

256 color led to some brilliant colorschemes too, and nowadays we have practically unlimited colors, so the question I'd like to ask is

'How many colors do you think is needed to make a good game, all other things being equal?'

title: Re: Color
content:
I think having 16 colours to choose from when Keen modding helps me a bit.

I am pretty crap at drawing things, and I find that the limited amount of colours to choose from basically decides what colour I should use. Although I can see how it'd be annoying to only have 16 colours when you want to draw something and it needs a non-included colour (while still needing to use all of the first 16 colours).

I'd vote 16 - 256. Any more colours than that and I'd be in too far over my head. But that's just my preference when drawing and doesn't have much to do with the actual question.


I had a bad experience while playing Space Quest CGA when I was a child, and although the lack of colours in the game had nothing to do with that, I am still 'freaked' (for lack of a better word) by CGA games. So perhaps I'm a bit biased, but in answering the question, I think a great game can be made with 16 colours. Like Keen was.

title: Re: Color
content:
You can't exactly expect to make a next gen first person shooter with only 16 colours.
Even if the textures would only be 16 colours, lighting/shading alone would mean a lot more colours would automatically be generated.

Well, if those textures were used in a current/next gen engine anyway.
If you look at the original Doom you'll find it uses a limited (256) palette.
Moving away from a wall in the dark backwards, you'll find the wall will appear darker and darker.
You'll also notice for instance dark blue colours will revert to a dark gray if there isn't a dark enough blue.
Actually this is a bogus example, but it should explain my point.
I'm really happy this palette business is a thing of the past when it comes to creating textures.

To answer your question, I think 16 colours can still make for a good game, whereas 4 colours simply looks too... bland, or rather too bright.
Not monochrome either, maybe duochrome or something if that's a word, but just not enough to make anything seem "real" enough.Retodon8

title: Re: Color
content:
This is real hard to say, it all depends on what you are trying to pull off. If you are trying to make a 3D ultra realistic game then obviously the more you can get the number of colors displayed to the number that humans can see in real life will be better.

Now if you are talking about a "made at home" dealie it still depends on what style you are trying to pull off. Personally for sprites I prefer to use a limited palette to begin with but I do find 16 colors to be very restrictive. I like to use few colors when coloring but I like to have many shades to start with. Um... understand?

But regardless it doesn't matter about the graphics it matters about the game play. This is the fundamental fact that ID fails to grasp. The same reason why Duke Nukem 3D kicked Quake's butt even though Quake had 16 bit color while DN3D had 256. (I believe.)-----------------------
